title: Opening Bell: U.S. Futures Tumble On China Trade Lawsuit; Pound Hits 2016 Low
text:
U.S. futures tumble as China's trade tariffs accusations spur risk off

Pound hits 2016 flash-crash low as PM Johnson threatens general elections

U.S. Treasury yields drops near 2016 levels ahead of Fedspeak

WTI breaks below $55

Key Events

September trading for , and futures started on the wrong foot this morning as investors struggled to find stability amid conflicting trade reports and signs of a global slowdown, while European and Asian stocks were hit by Brexit chaos and civil unrest in Hong Kong.

Meanwhile, the plunged to the lowest level since the 2016 “flash crash”, as British Prime Minister Boris Johnson threatened to call general elections for Oct. 14 if the Parliament voted a bill—before its forced closure on Sept. 9—to stop the “no-deal” Brexit he spearheaded.

STOXX 600 Daily Chart

The slid lower, ending a three-day advance, with mining and retail shares leading the losses.

Technically, the drop followed Friday’s shooting star, whose highs tested the top of a potential rising wedge, bearish after the 8.6% tumble from the July 25 highs to the Aug. 15 lows. The price also found resistance by the 50 and 100 DMAs, revealing further technical pressure atop the pattern.

GBP/USD Macrotrend

With the exception of 2016’s brief nosedive, the $1.2 level hit by cable on Tuesday was last seen in 1985.

In the earlier Asian session, most regional equities fell after reports China against the United States at the World Trade Organization, saying the U.S.’s latest tariff moves violated agreements reached in an Osaka meeting in June.

Hong Kong’s slid 0.39% as calls mounted for the city to return to British citizenship. At the opposite side of the spectrum, New Zealand’s outperformed (+1.43%) as companies with reliable dividends such as Contact Energy (NZ: ) and Meridian Energy (NZ: ) added to an outlook of low interest rates.

Global Financial Affairs

UST 10-Year Daily Chart

Meanwhile, yields on Treasurys slipped back below 1.5% to only 1 basis point above the Aug. 28 low—the most depressed level since July 2016. Technically, yields are developing a third back-to-back continuation pattern, each of whose downside breakout was the start of the follow-up bearish pattern.

DXY Daily Chart

The inched higher for the fourth day out of five, hitting the highest price since May 11, 2017. Technically, the greenback completed a H&S continuation pattern, whose uptrend has been supported by the 200 DMA all year.

WTI Daily Chart

In commodities, extended Monday’s drop below $55 on renewed fears a global slowdown would depress demand. Technically, the price ticked lower for a third session after it tested the 200 DMA, back into a falling channel.

Up ahead

British MPs start discussions on an emergency plan to take control of the legislature’s business on Tuesday evening in London.

Final euro-area data for August are due on Wednesday.

Fed speakers include New York Fed’s on Wednesday and Fed Chair on Friday.

The U.S. on Friday is projected to show the widely-watched nonfarm payrolls rose by 158,000 in August, versus 164,000 the month prior. Estimates are for to be steady at 3.7% and the rate of increase to slow to 3.0%.

Market Moves

Stocks

The dropped 0.3%.

Currencies

The Dollar Index advanced 0.34%.

The slid 0.3% to $1.0942.

The British pound tumbled 0.7% to $1.1981.

The strengthened 0.1% to 106.09 per dollar.

The fell 0.4%.

Bonds

The yield on 10-year Treasurys slid one basis point to 1.49%.

The yield on Treasurys dropped one basis point to 1.49%.

Britain’s yield slipped six basis points to 0.382%.

Commodities

West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.1% to $54.57 a barrel.

tumbled 1.6% to $2.51 a pound.
